desc: Fort George R.C. school first appears on Department of Mines and Resources Annual Report, offering grades 1 to 5; school may have been open as early as 1930.
School is divided into two types of classrooms, English and French, until 1968 when the school was to be completely French, having switched fully to the Quebec curriculum.
First record of day school students attending school
Principal informs regional superintendent that he will begin to offer grades 7 and 8 in the fall; previous agreement was for grades up to 6.
January: Principal=s Monthly report indicates grade 7 being offered.
Principal's Monthly reports for March and May indicate that a grade 9 day pupil was attending school.

School was to be restricted to grades 1 to 6, after which pupils would be sent to La Tuque; Administrator apparently ignored this Departmental directive as in 1966/67 there was still a combined class of grades 6 to 8.
Beginning in September 1967 grades Pre 1/Kindergarten to 7 are offered, though in 1970-71 school is still listed as being for grades 1 to 8
Ste. Therese Indian School is separate from Couture Residence
School and Residence turned over to Cree School Board through lease agreement on July 1, 1978.

writtenAgreements.desc: Contract with Indianescom covering advisory and liasion duties in connection with Indian Student residence for one year beginning April 1, 1973.
Contract with Oblate Indian & Eskimo Council covering co-ordinating and liasion duties in connection with Indian Student residence, signed June 10, 1974.

While Government owned residential schools were covered by the October 19, 1961 operation agreements, Church owned schools were only required to send in a copy of their budget; this resulted in no formal agreements with the Oblates specifically covering the school.
Audit report remarks that 1972 service agreement signed between Couture Residence and St. Joseph Mission was not approved by Department.

School operates under Treasury Board Minute # 585658 dated October 19, 1961 as a church owned residence; a service contract between the Department and the Couture Residence was made on January 19, 1972, but was never signed.
There is no formal agreement with the residence; it has been operated under an oral understanding with the Department; correspondence which construed to a formal agreement was destroyed in a flood.

All efforts to locate a formal agreement to cover payments to the Church operating the residence have been unsuccessful; there is no useful purpose to be served by the Department retroactively engaging in negotiations for an agreement.
The Department no long administers the residence; related files are closed

additionalInformation.notes: Until September the school was overcrowded with enrolment of some 90 children; opening of Pointe-Blue IRS dropped enrolment to authorized level.
Fire Inspection report states that school has little fire protection.
No protection for fire; classrooms are located in old quarters, and the number of cubic feet is under standard.
Inspection report indicates that the five classrooms at the school are old, and present a fire hazard.
